Compare this to claude-loop's agents and domain adapters. Focus on: skill definition patterns, how skills are invoked, extensibility, and the relationship between skills and tools.
acceptanceCriteria: Document Cowork's skills architecture

Propose how claude-loop could adopt a 'skills' paradigm

userStories.notes: Completed comprehensive skills architecture analysis. Documented Cowork's 3-tier progressive disclosure (metadata → instructions → resources), filesystem-based architecture enabling code bundling and on-demand loading. Compared with claude-loop's 34-agent registry system using hybrid keyword+semantic matching. Identified zero capability overlap (Cowork: business docs, claude-loop: dev tools). Proposed hybrid architecture: skills for deterministic operations (validation, generation), agents for generative tasks (analysis, strategy). Recommended 5 high-value skills to create: prd-validator (P0), test-scaffolder (P1), commit-formatter (P1), api-spec-generator (P2), cost-optimizer (P2). Created docs/analysis/cowork-skills-architecture.md (655 lines, 3,500 words, 14 sections). Commit: 1a2191c

userStories.notes: Completed comprehensive integration & connectors analysis. Documented Cowork's MCP-based connector architecture (50+ connectors, OAuth management, third-party ecosystem). userStories.title: Critical Analysis with Product Strategy Lens
userStories.description: Apply product strategy thinking (monopoly lens: proprietary tech, network effects, economies of scale, brand) to both Cowork and claude-loop. Identify competitive moats, strategic advantages, and where each tool fits in the market landscape.
acceptanceCriteria: Apply monopoly lens to Cowork's design decisions
Apply monopoly lens to claude-loop's design decisions
Identify strategic advantages of each approach
Propose strategic positioning for claude-loop post-Cowork
Create a markdown document: docs/analysis/cowork-strategy-analysis.md
userStories.notes: Completed comprehensive strategic analysis applying Peter Thiel's monopoly lens (proprietary tech, network effects, economies of scale, brand) to both Cowork and claude-loop. Cowork scored 44/50 (highly promising monopoly candidate) with primary moat being ecosystem network effects (50+ MCP connectors, 87% strength) and brand trust premium (Anthropic backing, 93% strength). Claude-loop scored 36/50 (solid) with primary moat being proprietary self-improvement architecture (100% strength, 7-10 year durability) but weak network effects (33% strength). Strategic recommendation: claude-loop should double down on differentiation (reliability, multi-day projects, self-improvement) rather than compete on simplicity with Cowork. Market segmentation is natural: Cowork targets non-technical users for ad-hoc tasks, claude-loop targets developers for complex multi-day projects. Created 15,000-word strategic analysis document covering: moat analysis for both tools, comparative advantages, strategic positioning recommendations, 3-phase roadmap (network effects, enterprise features), and competitive landscape assessment. Document location: docs/analysis/cowork-strategy-analysis.md

userStories.title: Contrarian Challenge - Question Cowork's Assumptions
userStories.description: Apply contrarian thinking to pressure-test Cowork's design. What problems might Cowork create? What assumptions might be wrong? What limitations might become apparent at scale? Use this to help claude-loop avoid similar pitfalls.
acceptanceCriteria: Identify 5+ potential problems with Cowork's approach
Identify assumptions that may not hold at scale
Identify anti-patterns to avoid in claude-loop
Propose defensible design choices for claude-loop
Create a markdown document: docs/analysis/cowork-contrarian-view.md
userStories.notes: Completed comprehensive contrarian analysis identifying 8 major problem categories with Cowork's design: (1) Invisible failure cascade from async execution, (2) Trust erosion from colleague metaphor overconfidence, (3) Auditability crisis with transient traces, (4) Ecosystem lock-in via MCP connectors, (5) Workspace scope creep beyond folder boundaries, (6) Emergent planning fragility in complex workflows, (7) Chrome pairing security theatre, (8) Natural language specification ambiguity. Identified 10 assumptions that may not hold at scale (folder boundaries, emergent planning scalability, transient traces sufficiency, etc.). Identified 10 anti-patterns to avoid (invisible failure, overconfident completion, proprietary lock-in, etc.). Proposed 10 defensible design principles for claude-loop (pessimistic by default, transparency over convenience, auditability first-class, determinism over flexibility, etc.). Created comprehensive 895-line document with 30+ specific issues, concrete failure scenarios, and strategic positioning recommendations. Commit: d6f311d

userStories.title: First Principles Analysis - Core Problems & Solutions
userStories.description: Break down to first principles: What core problems do Cowork and claude-loop solve? What are the root causes? What are the fundamental constraints? Use 5 Whys analysis to understand the deep problem space, then reason from fundamentals about optimal solutions.
acceptanceCriteria: Conduct 5 Whys analysis on both tools' problem spaces
Identify fundamental constraints (context limits, costs, latency, etc.)
Reason from first principles about optimal solutions
Identify where Cowork and claude-loop converge/diverge in solution space
Create a markdown document: docs/analysis/cowork-first-principles.md
userStories.notes: Completed comprehensive first principles analysis. Conducted 5 Whys for both Cowork (root causes: mental model mismatch, trust deficit, UX complexity) and claude-loop (root causes: stateless conversations, lack of persistent memory, absence of quality gates, reproducibility problem). Identified 5 fundamental constraints: context window limits (200k tokens), cost structure ($0.25-$75/M), latency requirements (seconds to days), reliability vs adaptability trade-off, trust & control. Reasoned from first principles about optimal solutions for 3 scenarios: minimize friction (Cowork optimal), maximize reliability (claude-loop optimal), balance both (hybrid approach). Identified 5 convergence points (selective context loading, async execution, transparency, safety boundaries, file system access) and 8 divergence points (target user, task duration, specification, planning, execution, quality assurance, audit trail, parallelism). Proposed mode switching as meta-principle. Created docs/analysis/cowork-first-principles.md (6,200 words, 9 sections, 8 tables, all acceptance criteria met).

userStories.notes: Completed comprehensive 3-phase implementation roadmap. Phase 1 (Quick Wins, 6-8 weeks): Enhanced Progress Indicators (1.5w), PRD Templates (1.5w), Workspace Sandboxing (2w), Checkpoint Confirmations (2w). Phase 2 (Foundations, 20-24 weeks): Skills Architecture (4-6w), Quick Task Mode (4-5w), Daemon Mode (5-6w), Visual Progress Dashboard (4-5w). Phase 3 (Differentiators, 32-40 weeks): Adaptive Story Splitting (8-10w), Dynamic PRD Generation (8-10w), Multi-LLM Quality Review (10-12w), Real-Time Notifications (4-5w), Interactive PRD Builder (6-8w), Rollback & Undo (6-7w). Included success metrics for each phase (NPS, adoption rates, quality improvements), phase transition criteria (stability requirements, user satisfaction thresholds), risk mitigation strategy, resource planning (team composition, budget estimates), and alternative paths (Cowork parity only, strategic differentiation focus, minimum viable evolution). Total timeline: 58-72 weeks (14-18 months) with parallelization. Created docs/roadmap/cowork-inspired-roadmap.md (comprehensive roadmap document with 15 features across 3 phases, all acceptance criteria exceeded).
